Fig. 1 Crystal structure of Sup-B, [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 (Bu= n-butyl). Light green are Mg, green are Cl, grey are carbon, and red are oxygen atoms.(For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of the article.) Fig. 2 SEM images of the supports and the catalysts. Fig. 3 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption (filled/open) isotherms of Cat-A (circles) and Cat-B (diamonds). Fig. 4 PXRD patterns of the supports and the catalysts. Reflections from the sample holder are denoted by asterisks. Fig. 5 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra of the supports and the catalysts. Fig. 6 DRIFT spectra of the supports and catalysts from the ν as(C–O–C) region. Fig. 7 SEM images of the copolymer particles polymerized with Cat-A and Cat-B. Ziegler–Natta catalysts supported on crystalline and amorphous MgCl2/THF complexes Sami Pirinen a Kumudini Jayaratne b Peter Denifl b Tuula T. Pakkanen a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Eastern Finland, P.O. Box 111, FI-80101 Joensuu, Finland Department of Chemistry University of Eastern Finland, P.O. Box 111 Joensuu FI-80101 Finland b Borealis Polymers Oy, P.O. Box 330, FI-06101 Porvoo, Finland Borealis Polymers Oy P.O. Box 330 Porvoo FI-06101 Finland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +358 50 4354379. Graphical abstract Two MgCl2/THF/TiCl4 (THF=tetrahydrofuran) catalysts were prepared with MgCl2/THF supports having an amorphous (Sup-A) or a molecular compound structure, [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 (Bu= n-butyl) (Sup-B). Amorphous catalyst A had a normal supported Ziegler–Natta-type structure with low donor and titanium contents (the molar ratios, THF/Mg=0.14 and Ti/Mg=0.17), while catalyst B had a molecular type of composition with high donor and titanium contents (the molar ratios, THF/Mg=0.84 and Ti/Mg=0.80). Despite the different composition, Cat-A and Cat-B had some structural similarities as evidenced from the powder X-ray diffraction data and nuclear magnetic resonance and infrared spectroscopy results. Polymerization studies showed that these catalysts are highly active in copolymerization of ethylene and 1-butene. Although there were differences in the composition and the structure between the catalysts, they produced almost similar copolymers as indicated by the molecular weight, molecular weight distribution, comonomer content, melting point, and crystallinity of the copolymers. Keywords MgCl2 support Molecular compound TiCl4 Ziegler–Natta catalyst Copolymerization 1 Introduction Heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts play a key role in the production of polyolefins [1]. Polypropylene and polyethylene that have numerous applications are examples of polymers that are most often produced with Ziegler–Natta catalysts. These catalysts are usually comprised of MgCl2 support, Lewis bases, TiCl4 active species, and cocatalyst aluminum alkyl [2–5]. One of the key factors in the catalyst preparation is the surface structure of the support. Use of MgCl2 as a support for Ziegler–Natta catalysts was an important breakthrough in the sense of the catalytic activity and polymer properties [6,7]. Even though MgCl2 is often considered merely as a support, its role in the formation of the active centers is crucial and therefore a great attention is paid to the preparation of a suitable MgCl2 support for Ziegler–Natta catalyst [8,9]. Very often MgCl2 is mechanically or chemically transformed into a structurally disordered form i.e. “activated” form or δ-form [10–15], but crystalline MgCl2 can also be used as a support. An example of molecular compounds that are used as supports are MgCl2–ethanol adducts, but other alcohols can also be used. It is to be noted that when contacting these MgCl2–alcohol adducts with TiCl4, alcohol is removed, and typically, the structure changes from a crystalline to an amorphous material possessing a high surface area [16–19]. Other typical molecular compounds that have been used as a support for Ziegler–Natta catalysts are MgCl2/tetrahydrofuran (THF) complexes [20]. MgCl2/THF/TiCl4 catalysts produce polyethylene with a good activity and have a good hydrogen response [21–23]. For activity improvement, the active center distribution can be modified with additives such as ZnCl2 and SiCl4 added to the MgCl2/THF/TiCl4 catalytic system [24]. Also use of vanadium catalysts instead of titanium catalysts can improve the activity and comonomer response in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization with MgCl2/THF supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts [25,26]. In our previous study [27], the effect of THF on the morphology and the structure of synthesized MgCl2 were studied. It was found that a transition from a fully crystalline to structurally disordered complexes can be controlled by adjusting the amount of THF in the autoclave synthesis of MgCl2. The single crystals obtained had an open dicubane structure, [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 (Bu= n-butyl), revealing information about THF binding. In this study, the molecular compound [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 and an amorphous MgCl2/THF complex are used as supports for preparation of Ti-based Ziegler–Natta catalysts in an autoclave. Compositions and structures of the two catalysts are compared on the basis of chemical analysis, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and spectroscopic characterization results. The prepared catalysts are found to have high catalytic activity in the copolymerization of ethylene and 1-butene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Magnesium (Acros Organics) was dried in an oven at 110°C overnight before use. Iodine was from Merck and used as received. Octane, 1-chlorobutane, and THF were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and dried with 3Å molecular sieves before use. TiCl4 (Sigma–Aldrich) was used as received. All support and catalyst synthesis and characterizations were performed under inert gas unless otherwise mentioned. 2.2 Synthesis of supports and catalysts The support was synthesized as described previously in the literature [27]. Autoclave was packed with Mg (0.5g, 0.021mol), few small crystals of iodine, octane (20mL), 1-chlorobutane (4.6mL, 0.044mol), and THF (0.005 or 0.041mol). The autoclave was heated at 130°C for 2h with stirring. The powder was filtered, washed with octane, and transferred into an autoclave with octane (10mL) and TiCl4 (10mL). The autoclave was heated at 110°C for 2h with stirring. The product was filtered, washed with octane, and dried in vacuum at room temperature. 2.3 Characterization of supports and catalysts PXRD measurements were performed with a Bruker AXS D8 Advance instrument. For the PXRD measurements, samples were placed on a special steel-made sample holder and protected from contact with air by a Mylar film. The step size was 0.05° and time per step 8s. SEM measurements were carried out with a Hitachi S-4800 microscope with a voltage of 3kV in the measurements. The sample was quickly fixed on a tape and immediately moved to the loading chamber of SEM. Solid state 13C cross polarization magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded with a Bruker AMX-400 spectrometer with a spinning rate of 4500Hz, relaxation delay of 4s, contact time of 3ms, and number of scans 10,000. Glycine was used as an external reference. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured with a Nicolet Impact 400D with the diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) method. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption was measured at 77K with an Autosorb iQ2 (Quantachrome instruments) analyzer. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was determined from a BET plot at p/p 0 =0.05–0.30 and the total pore volume for pores with diameter less than 42nm was determined at p/p 0 =0.95. 2.4 Copolymerizations All polymerizations were conducted in a 3L stainless steel semi-batch reactor using 1.25L of propane and triethyl aluminum (TEA) as the co-catalyst. The polymerization procedure was conducted as follows: 1.25L of propane and the desired amount of 1-butene and hydrogen was added and the contents of the reactor was stirred and heated to the reaction temperature (85°C). Ethylene was then introduced followed by the co-catalyst and the catalyst and ethylene was fed on demand to maintain the specific pressure for the specific length (1h) of the polymerization reaction. The reactor was maintained and controlled at the desired reaction temperature throughout the polymerization. Upon completion, the ethylene flow was stopped and the reactor pressure slowly vented off. The reactor was opened and the polymer product was collected and dried in a fume hood overnight. Slurry polymerization conditions: C2 mol% – 4.8, H2/C2 (mol/kmol) – 40, C4/C2 (mol/kmol) – 770, Al/Ti (mol/mol) – 15. 2.5 Characterization of copolymers Molar mass averages (M w and M n ) and molar mass distributions (M w /M n ) of the polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography according to ISO 16014-4:2003 and ASTM D 6474-99 standards with a Waters GPCV2000 instrument. Two GMHXL-HT columns and one G7000HXL-HT TSK-gel column (Tosoh Bioscience) were used with stabilized 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene as a solvent at 140°C (flow rate 1mL/min). Universal calibration was performed with polystyrene standards. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed with a Mettler Toledo DSC823e instrument. During the measurement a nitrogen gas flow (50mL/min) was used. The DSC program included three parts: first the sample was heated from 25 to 210°C, secondly the sample was cooled back to 25°C, and thirdly the sample was heated again to 210°C from which data was analyzed with a STARe thermal analysis software. In all steps a heating rate of 10°C/min was applied and the reported values are an average of three measurements. For the SEM measurements the polymer particles were fixed on a tape and sputtered with a thin layer of gold to reduce charging of the sample surface during the measurements. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition of supports and catalysts Two Ziegler–Natta catalysts were prepared by using two different types of MgCl2/THF supports (Table 1 ). Support A (Sup-A) with THF/Mg molar ratio 0.28 has a disordered structure, typical of δ-MgCl2. Support B (Sup-B) with THF/Mg molar ratio 1.21 is a molecular compound with an open dicubane structure, [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 (Bu= n-butyl), shown in Fig. 1 . More detailed information about the supports can be found in our earlier study [27]. Catalyst A (Cat-A) and catalyst B (Cat-B) were prepared by mixing Sup-A and Sup-B with an excess of TiCl4 in an autoclave at 110°C. According to Table 1, Cat-B has a Ti content over twice as high as that of Cat-A and has a Ti/Mg molar ratio of 0.80, exceptionally high for a Ziegler–Natta catalyst. By comparing the THF/Mg ratios of the supports and the catalysts in Table 1 it is clear that part of THF was removed from the supports when they were brought in contact with TiCl4. The THF/Mg molar ratio 0.14 of Cat-A is only half of the THF/Mg ratio 0.28 of Sup-A. There is also a clear drop in the THF/Mg molar ratio from 1.21 for Sup-B to 0.84 of Cat-B. Due to the notable decrease in the THF content it is likely that the structure of Sup-B has not survived in the reaction with TiCl4. 3.2 Characterization of support and catalyst particles with SEM and nitrogen adsorption SEM images from the supports and the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Sup-A is in a form of amorphous particles and Sup-B as single crystals. The particles of Cat-A have an amorphous morphology similar to Sup-A, but the larger particles are covered with smaller ones. The particles of Cat-B show different types of morphology varying from amorphous particles similar to those in Cat-A to more crystalline particles possessing diamond and rod-like shapes. For both catalysts the size of particles, according to SEM, varied greatly as agglomerated particles from few to tens of microns were observed. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms for the catalysts have significant differences in their features (Fig. 3 ). Cat-A has the type II isotherm presenting a multilayer adsorption, typical for a macroporous or a non-porous material [28]. The hysteresis loop for Cat-A, typical for materials containing agglomerates of particles, suggests the presence of slit-shaped pores. The isotherm of Cat-B also indicates macroporous or non-porous adsorption characteristics. In comparison to the isotherm for Cat-A, only a small increase in the adsorption at low p/p 0 values and only a slight hysteresis at p/p 0 >0.7 are observed for Cat-B. The BET specific surface areas for Sup-A and Sup-B were 19 and 2m2/g, respectively, whereas the surface areas of the catalysts were 51m2/g for Cat-A and 22m2/g for Cat-B. Although the BET method is not very reliable for Ziegler–Natta catalysts [29], an apparent increase in the specific surface area is obtained with interaction of TiCl4 with Sup-A and Sup-B. Also pore volumes 0.13cm3/g for Cat-A and 0.07cm3/g for Cat-B were clearly higher than those for Sup-A and Sup-B (0.05 and 0.004cm3/g, respectively). 3.3 Characterization of catalysts with PXRD, NMR, and IR methods The PXRD pattern of Sup-A in Fig. 4 shows MgCl2 having a high structural disorder indicated by the broad reflections at 29–37° and 49–54° 2θ. The same features of disordered MgCl2 are also present in the PXRD pattern of Cat-A, but additional reflections are also observed with the most intense ones at 11.0, 12.5, 16.5, 30.1, 35.7, and 37.3° 2θ. These reflections are probably related to the Ti-complexes formed during the catalyst synthesis. The structure of Cat-B is mainly crystalline, but is clearly different from the structure of Sup-B as can be seen in Fig. 4. This was expected as the THF content in Cat-B (molar ratio THF/Mg 0.84) is notably lower than in Sup-B (THF/Mg 1.21) due to the treatment with TiCl4. The PXRD pattern of Cat-B exhibits the same Ti-complex related reflections as Cat-A, but with higher intensity. A number of other sharp reflections are observed, the strongest one located at 13.1° 2θ. Also, the weak, broad reflections observed at 29–37° and 49–53° 2θ indicate the presence of δ-MgCl2. It seems that Cat-B contains at least three components having a different crystalline order. The 13C CP/MAS NMR spectrum of Sup-A (Fig. 5 ) is simple showing two narrow signals at 25.3 and 70.4ppm corresponding to β- and α-carbons of THF bound to Mg. Besides these signals the 13C NMR spectrum of Cat-A shows signals at 14.5, 23.9, 31.5, and 33.7ppm arising from octane solvent trapped inside the catalyst particles. Also, weak, broad signals are observed at around 44 and 78ppm for Cat-A. Due to different environments of THF molecules in [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2, the 13C NMR spectrum of Sup-B shows multiple signals arising from β-carbons of THF at 25.1 and 25.7ppm and from α-carbons of THF at 69.6, 70.0, and 70.4ppm [27]. Signals at 6.4, 13.6, and 32.1ppm are arising from the butyl groups in [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2. In the 13C NMR spectrum of Cat-B only single carbon resonances at 25.3 and 70.4ppm are observed for β- and α-carbons of THF bound to Mg and no signals arising from the butyl groups are observed. This indicates that the crystalline form of Sup-B has not survived as was already evidenced from the PXRD data. Unlike Cat-A, Cat-B does not contain any solvent trapped inside the particles according to 13C NMR. The weak, broad signals observed for Cat-A at around 44 and 78ppm are stronger in the 13C NMR spectrum of Cat-B probably due to higher Ti content of Cat-B than that of Cat-A. Broad signals at 82.0, 78.7, 44.9, 28.2, and 23.9ppm are observed for Cat-B. Almost all of these signals could be explained with THF bound to Ti. However, signal at 44.9ppm indicates that a new compound has formed in the synthesis of the catalyst, because this signal cannot be attributed to any of the starting reagents or their complexes. A possible explanation for this signal could be the formation of 4-chloro-butan-1-oxy compound originated from THF ring-opening. This reaction has been reported recently [23] and it was suggested that the ring-opening of THF molecule might occur due to the treatment of MgCl2/THF complex with TiCl4. The broad signals at 82.0, 78.7, 28.2, and 23.9 may originate from carbon atoms of the closed or the ring-opened THF molecules bound to titanium. The DRIFT spectra of the two catalysts in Fig. 6 indicate clearly the presence of THF molecules bound to Ti. Both catalysts show an intense absorption band at 990cm−1 which is not detected in the DRIFT spectra of the supports. This absorption comes from asymmetric stretching vibration of C–O bond of THF bound to Ti(IV) [9]. For THF bound to Mg the absorption band ν as(C–O–C) maxima is observed at 1021cm−1 with shoulder at 1038cm−1 for Sup-A and at 1027cm−1 for Sup-B. In the DRIFT spectra of the catalysts this absorption band is clearly divided into two bands. For Cat-A these bands are at 1017 and 1041cm−1 and for Cat-B at 1020 and 1042cm−1. Especially in the case of Cat-B the chemical environment of THF molecules has clearly changed as was already observed from the 13C NMR measurements. 3.4 Copolymerizations of ethylene and 1-butene The performance of Cat-A and Cat-B in the copolymerization of ethylene and 1-butene was studied. Cat-A has a composition of a typical supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst with low THF and Ti contents whereas Cat-B has high THF and Ti contents with a molecular type of composition. However, both catalysts were found to be highly active in ethylene/1-butene copolymerization with activities comparable to commercial catalysts (Table 2 ). The catalyst based activity was similar for both catalysts, but the titanium based activity was clearly higher for Cat-A, which had lower Ti content (6.0wt%) compared to that of Cat-B (13.0wt%). Based on the characterization results, Cat-B contains different types of Ti-complexes. The lower titanium based activity of Cat-B suggests that some of these Ti-complexes are not active or they have a low activity in ethylene/1-butene copolymerization. Besides the similar catalytic activity of Cat-A and Cat-B, the characteristic features of the copolymers produced are quite similar (Table 2). For both catalysts the molar mass distribution (M w /M n ) was around 4.5, which is typical for heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts. Due to several different Ti-complexes in Cat-B, it could have been expected that the molar mass distribution would be broader for copolymer of Cat-B than that of copolymer of Cat-A. The comonomer response was good for both catalysts. The copolymer prepared with Cat-A contained 3.7wt% of 1-butene while the copolymer produced by Cat-B incorporated 4.6wt% of 1-butene. Due to higher comonomer content introduced by Cat-B the crystallinity (Table 2) of the copolymer obtained with Cat-B is slightly lower (41.3%) compared to that of the copolymer obtained with Cat-A (43.8%). However, the differences in the crystallinity are very small and the melting points of the copolymers obtained with Cat-A and Cat-B are almost identical. As all polymer characterization values are almost similar, it is likely that the active sites present in Cat-A and Cat-B are alike despite the fact that the catalysts had differences in their composition, chemical structure, and morphology. On the other hand, the different textural characteristics (surface area and pore volume) of Cat-A and Cat-B as well as catalyst morphology can have influence on the polymerization behavior through monomer accessibility to active sites and fragmentation of the catalyst particles. The porous nature of Cat-A facilitates the fragmentation of the catalyst particles and the morphology of the catalyst particles is replicated into copolymer particles as can be seen from the SEM image in Fig. 7 . Copolymer produced by Cat-B had an unusual morphology: particles possessing a worm-like shape. Similar particles were also observed in copolymer obtained with Cat-A, but their proportion was low. 4 Conclusions The structure and the morphology of the support were found to influence the final structure of the MgCl2/THF/TiCl4 Ziegler–Natta catalysts. In the case of the amorphous support, the disordered structure of MgCl2 was retained in the catalyst. The crystalline MgCl2 support gave an almost fully crystalline catalyst although with a different crystalline structure. Despite the differences in composition and morphology, the two catalysts were highly active in the ethylene/1-butene copolymerization. Interestingly, although Cat-A and Cat-B have THF/Mg molar ratios 0.14 and 0.84 respectively, the polymerization behavior is similar, suggesting THF is incorporated in the bulk MgCl2 with no direct interactions with active Ti centers. This work shows that the MgCl2/THF complexes synthesized in an autoclave reaction are suitable as supports for Ziegler–Natta catalysts to obtain ethylene/1-butene copolymer with a high activity. Acknowledgments We gratefully acknowledge financial support from the Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation and European Union/European Regional Development Fund (grant 70054/09). coredata.dc:description: Two MgCl2/THF/TiCl4 (THF=tetrahydrofuran) catalysts were prepared with MgCl2/THF supports having an amorphous (Sup-A) or a molecular compound structure, [Mg3Cl5(THF)4Bu]2 (Bu= n-butyl) (Sup-B). Amorphous catalyst A had a normal supported Ziegler–Natta-type structure with low donor and titanium contents (the molar ratios, THF/Mg=0.14 and Ti/Mg=0.17), while catalyst B had a molecular type of composition with high donor and titanium contents (the molar ratios, THF/Mg=0.84 and Ti/Mg=0.80). Despite the different composition, Cat-A and Cat-B had some structural similarities as evidenced from the powder X-ray diffraction data and nuclear magnetic resonance and infrared spectroscopy results. Polymerization studies showed that these catalysts are highly active in copolymerization of ethylene and 1-butene. Although there were differences in the composition and the structure between the catalysts, they produced almost similar copolymers as indicated by the molecular weight, molecular weight distribution, comonomer content, melting point, and crystallinity of the copolymers.
coredata.dc:title: Ziegler–Natta catalysts supported on crystalline and amorphous MgCl2/THF complexes
